Yes, I can provide you with some examples of academic performance improvements in gender-segregated classrooms:

1. A study published in the Journal of Educational Research found that girls in all-girls schools outperformed their peers in co-ed schools in mathematics and science.

2. According to a British study conducted by the National Foundation for Educational Research, students in single-sex schools achieved higher grades in mathematics, science, and foreign languages than their peers in co-ed schools.

3. A meta-analysis of 184 studies on the outcomes of single-sex education found that gender-segregated classrooms could lead to better academic outcomes for both boys and girls, especially in areas such as math, science, and language arts.

However, it is important to note that these findings are not universal and may depend on a variety of factors such as the quality of teaching, the specific curriculum, and socioeconomic background of the students.
